tossups.question: Among the Breslov Hasidim, this Hebrew word names a set of ten Psalms chosen by Rebbe Nachman to be recited after wet dreams. Emil Fackenheim claimed that t’shuvah, in the form of the state of Israel, constituted a “fragmentary” form of an activity denoted by this word; Fackenheim also outlined “Foundations for Future Jewish thought” in a book titled for a translation of this word. According to Isaac Luria, the shattering of the ten vessels containing the sefirot brings about a stage named after this word, in which holy “sparks” trapped in the qliphoth [klee-FOHT] are freed. That stage in Kabbalah is paired with (*) Tohu. Michael Lerner founded a magazine named for this word, which many left-wing Jews use to refer to social justice activism. This word denotes a self-study book in which the Torah is printed both with and without vowels. For 10 points, what Hebrew word, when followed by “olam,” refers to the Jewish ideal of “repairing the world”?
tossups.answer: tikkun [or tikkun olam; or tikkun haKlali; or tikkun kor’im; prompt on olam by asking “What’s the other word?”] <Religion>

tossups.question: A doctor in this novel theorizes that people in groups transform into a new species he calls “group-man,” and compares them to cells “always getting some kind of infection.” This novel ends with an orator shining a light on a dead faceless man and rousing onlookers by claiming that the man “didn’t want nothing for himself.” Its protagonist is fired from a department store after being arrested for vagrancy, causing him to apply to join Harry Nilson’s organization. This novel contrasts Doc (*) Burton with a single-minded character who secretly encourages violence, such as when vigilantes burn down Anderson’s barn, destroying his harvest. After joining the Communist Party, its main character goes to the Torgas Valley, where he is mentored by the radical labor leader Mac McLeod. For 10 points, name this 1936 novel about Jim Nolan’s efforts to organize a strike of California apple-pickers, written by John Steinbeck.
tossups.answer: In Dubious Battle <Literature - American>

tossups.question: A 2016 article by Jardar ‎Østbø uses speech act theory to claim that this country has “securitized Spiritual-Moral Values.” The 2014 Foreign Affairs round-table “Faulty Powers” was a debate over the actions of this country between Stephen Sestanovich, John Mearsheimer, and Michael McFaul. A thinker from this country described fascism as “a redemptive excess of patriotic arbitrariness” after being inspired by Mussolini’s coup d’état. Timothy Snyder’s 2018 article entitled “God is” a person from this country examines a (*) Christian-fascist philosopher from here. Another thinker from this country was inspired by the Geographical Pivot of History to write The Last War of the World-Island, which built on Halford Mackinder’s claim that the “Heartland” was mainly located in this country. The Fourth Political Theory and The Foundation of Geopolitics are texts by another politically-influential thinker from this country. For 10 points, name this country where the ideas of Aleksandr Dugin and Ivan Ilyin inspire the government of Vladimir Putin.
tossups.answer: Russian Federation [prompt on Soviet Union or Union of Soviet Socialist Republics] <Mythology and Other>

tossups.question: Description acceptable. The ability of C·U·X·1 to upregulate cilia-related genes has been shown to play a role in the evolution of this phenomenon. The Weis–Fogh mechanism is a version of this phenomenon, and frenulo-retinacular coupling is an adaptation to increase the efficiency of this phenomenon. William Beebe [bee-bee] proposed an intermediate stage in the development of this phenomenon. Asynchronous muscle, which contracts multiple times per nerve impulse, is used in this (*) behavior in insects, in which it has direct and indirect forms. The arboreal and cursorial hypotheses aim to explain the development of this behavior. Halteres are sensory organs used in this behavior. Microraptor is thought to an intermediate in the evolution of this behavior, which may have been preceded by incline running. For 10 points, name this behavior found only in insects, pterosaurs, bats, and birds.
tossups.answer: powered flight [or word equivalents] <Science - Biology>

tossups.question: Marxist agitators in this state formed the Comrades’ Association, which inaugurated a struggle that won the abolition of vetti forced labor. The leader of the Khilafat Movement arranged for two princes from this state to marry Princess Niloufer and Princess Durrusehvar, the niece and daughter of Abdulmejid II. In the early 20th century, this state’s government founded the first Urdu-language university in India and uniquely issued its own currency. A ruler of this state, who used the Jacob Diamond as a paperweight after finding it in a shoe, was named richest man in the world in 1937 by Time. Qasim Razvi’s paramilitary Razakars were active in this state, the site of the (*) Golconda diamond mines. The Indian Army invaded this “princely state” in 1948’s Operation Polo after its ruler, the seventh Nizam from the Asaf Jahi dynasty, initially refused to join. For 10 points, name this historical state in the Deccan whose major city is the capital of Telangana and and is still the de jure capital of Andhra Pradesh.
tossups.answer: Hyderabad State <History - World>

tossups.question: .This city was the headquarters for an architect whose ashes were recently compressed to make a diamond ring by artist Jill Magid in protest against the Swiss furniture company Vitra. An architect’s house in this city includes a skylight above a railingless staircase, in a room with one wall painted bright pink. This city is home to a set of five tall, triangular-prism-shaped sculptures of varying heights, each painted a different color. The Transamerica Pyramid may have ripped off this city’s triangle-shaped Insignia Tower. The skyscraper-like (*) statues group Satellite Towers is located in this city. Giant stone reliefs sit above the eastern entrance to the Olympic stadium in this city’s University City. A “Polyforum” in this city houses the series The March of Humanity. An artist’s home in this city was turned into a museum dubbed “The Blue House.” For 10 points, name this city home to Chapultepec Castle.
tossups.answer: Mexico City [or Ciudad de México] (The unnamed architect is Luis Barragán.) <Arts - Audiovisual, Other>

tossups.question: S.J Bouma designed a small park known affectionately as “the little city with a smile” as a memorial for one member of this group, George Maduro. Another member of this group legendarily attempted to escape captivity by jumping out of a second-story window while tied to a chair. A neurologist led this group’s CS-6 faction, which targeted the Henneicke Column by planting bombs in mailboxes. Operation Silbertanne and the Putten Raid targeted this group, which was founded after the (*) February Strike and carried out attacks on Anton Mussert and the NSB. Arthur Seyss-Inquart was plagued by this group, some of whose members returned after escaping as “England Voyagers” by hopping boats in the North Sea. Members of this group were tortured by the SS at the “Orange Hotel” in the Hague. For 10 points, identify this group that opposed Nazi occupation of a nation ruled by Queen Wilhelmina.
tossups.answer: Dutch Resistance [or Netherlands Resistance, or Weerstand van de Nederland; Accept CS-6 before mentioned; anti-prompt on Dutch Communists or similar answers; prompt on partial answer] <History - European>

tossups.question: An anomaly in one of these values is potentially explained by a new massive spin-1 Z′ [“Z prime”] boson. A 50-foot superconducting magnet was moved by barge from Brookhaven National Lab to Fermilab to conduct a new experiment in order to verify that a 3-sigma measured difference in one of these values from its prediction was real. Another one of these values is theoretically predicted by using a summation of (*) 12,672 Feynman diagrams and has recently been measured to three parts in 10 to the 13. A version of this quantity is equal to a weighted sum of the other two, where the weights involve products of angular momentum quantum numbers; that version is named for Landé. For the electron, this value is corrected in QED by the fine structure constant over 2 pi and is very close to 2. For 10 points, name this dimensionless constant that equals the ratio of a particle’s observed magnetic moment to its angular momentum vector times the Bohr magneton.
tossups.answer: g-factor [or dimensionless magnetic moment; accept g minus 2 or anomalous magnetic dipole moment only before “Landé” is mentioned] <Science - Physics>

tossups.question: A letter from Franz Kafka, who loved this author, declares that reading him “fills me as if I were an old pig’s bladder.” The title character of a tragedy by this author laments her inability to tell apart the words “Bisse” and “Küsse” before stabbing herself with a dagger. This author’s final play was not performed during his lifetime because of a scene where the main character sees his open grave and desperately begs for his life. In that play by this author, (*) Princess Natalie crowns the title character with a laurel wreath after he expects to be executed for disobeying orders at the Battle of Fehrbellin. Along with her dogs, the title character of one of his plays gnaws on the corpse of Achilles; that play’s failure contributed to his decision to commit suicide alongside Henriette Vogel. For 10 points, name this 19th century German playwright of Prince Friedrich of Homburg and Penthesilea, who also wrote The Broken Jug and The Marquise of O––.
tossups.answer: Heinrich von Kleist <Literature - European>

tossups.question: Description acceptable. This figure’s features were given to a painter sitting on “The Idea Box of a Connoisseur” in an engraving by Paul Sandby. French sculptor Louis-François Roubiliac made a terracotta sculpture of this figure. This figure appears next to a drunken bear in a satire of Charles Churchill titled The Bruiser, and he stands on a chair in the foreground of a group portrait of The Wollaston Family. In another portrait, this figure stands next to a painting-within-a-painting that’s propped up against texts by Swift, Milton and Shakespeare. This figure “marries” a one-eyed counterpart in a (*) 1734 painting that depicts the title man “married to an old maid.” In a portrait, a palette to this figure’s right has the phrase “The Line of Beauty and Grace” printed on it, a reference to the painter’s treatise The Analysis of Beauty. “Trump” was the name of—for 10 points—what animal depicted in a self-portrait by the painter of A Rake’s Progress?
tossups.answer: William Hogarth’s dog [or Hogarth’s pug; accept Trump until it’s mentioned; prompt on partial answer] <Arts - Visual>

tossups.question: These people are the subject of a 2006 paper by Susan Rasmussen about their “Moving Beyond the Protest” by using the guitar as a symbol against unemployment. These people developed a one-stringed fiddle that is only played by women whose husbands were sent off to war and which is built by their Inaden caste. Along with the Wodaabe, these people race each other during the Cure Salée festival, where the winner is awarded a broadsword called a takoba. Because these creators of the (*) imzad frequently traverse dangerous terrain near Abalessa, a holy site in the Hoggar Mountains, they are considered some of the best offroad vehicle operators in the world. These speakers of the Tamasheq languages rebelled in 2012 against the government of Amadou Touré to create the state of Azawad. For 10 points, identify this nomadic Berber group in the Sahara known for their characteristic blue tagelmust.
tossups.answer: Tuareg People [or Touareg] <Modern World>

tossups.question: This drug addict supposedly told his wife Louisa, “My poor darling, you have killed [me]” after realizing that she had mixed up his magnesia and chloral bottles. This scientist liked to wow audiences by catching a falling glass cylinder during Christmas lectures. This man, whose reputation suffered after his “Belfast Address” challenged Christianity’s claim to cosmology, almost went on a suicide mission to recover the body of a man who failed to summit the (*) Matterhorn. He was the first man to spend a night on the summit of Mont Blanc, where he made temperature readings. This man succeeded his friend Michael Faraday at the Royal Institution. By adding gas to a test tube filled with air, this contemporary of Lord Rayleigh demonstrated to a skeptical John Ruskin how the sky gets its apparent color. The greenhouse effect was discovered by––for 10 points––what scientist whose namesake effect describes the scattering of light in a colloid?
tossups.answer: John Tyndall <Science - Chemistry>

tossups.question: In contrast to conventional readings, an essay by Christopher Holmes claims that this character does not die, but is symbolically expelled by his community. An essay by Gary Taylor argues that this character’s death deliberately evokes the dismemberment of Orpheus. The scene in which this character appears was usually cut in the eighteenth and nineteenth centuries, but was included in a 1937 production directed by Orson Welles, which depicted this man’s attackers as (*) fascists. This character only appears in Act 3, Scene 3, where he is ordered to answer questions directly, briefly, wisely, and truly. In response, he states that he is going to a funeral, and lives by the Capitol. After this subject of the essay “Bardicide” tries to correct four citizens about his identity, they resolve to “tear him for his bad verses.” For 10 points, name this character from Julius Caesar who is killed after being confused with a similarly named conspirator.
tossups.answer: Cinna the Poet [prompt on partial answers like Cinna] <Literature - Other/World>

tossups.question: In one work, this thinker wrote that the word “humanity” is often an “ideological instrument of imperialism” before paraphrasing Proudhon in stating that “whoever invokes humanity wants to cheat.” This thinker concluded that the “juristic form” is not “the form of aesthetic production” because the latter “knows no decision.” A commentator accused that work by this thinker of a “liberalism with the opposite polarity” that is constantly “oriented toward…war.” This thinker inspired a later philosopher by opening a book with the claim that the (*) “sovereign is he who decides on the exception.” Leo Strauss corresponded with this author of On Dictatorship after critiquing this thinker’s claim that politics is founded on an ideology-neutral distinction between friend and enemy. Giorgio Agamben’s Homo Sacer was inspired by—for 10 points—what German philosopher and Nazi Party member who wrote The Concept of the Political?
tossups.answer: Carl Schmitt <Philosophy>

tossups.question: Louis Brandeis negotiated the Protocols of Peace following different strikes in successive years by workers in this industry in New York and Chicago. A strike among workers in this industry was supported by society women such as Inez Milholland and Alva Belmont, the first ever “Mink Brigade.” A speech at the Cooper Union during the Uprising of the 20,000 led to the rise of a (*) Yiddish-speaking labor organizer in this industry. Emma Goldman, who once worked in this industry, was arrested for violating the Comstock Law in 1916 for giving a speech to men in this industry. Clara Lemlich advocated for workers in this industry, which saw a “Great Revolt” in 1910 and the “Uprising of the 20,000” in 1909. For 10 points, name this industry whose mostly female workers were represented by David Dubinsky and the ILGWU and suffered the Triangle Shirtwaist fire?
tossups.answer: garment industry [or clothing industry; cloak-making industry; or dressmaking industry; prompt on sewing industry; do not accept “textiles” ] <History - American>

tossups.question: In an E.M. Forster short story, an implied encounter with this figure in Ravello invigorates the feeble Eustace, who escapes confinement by jumping out a window with the hunky fisherboy Gennaro. At the end of a short story by Saki, a stag gores Sylvia Seltoun for removing grapes offered to a bronze statue of this figure. Elizabeth Barrett Browning’s late poem “A Musical Instrument” asks what this figure was doing “down in the reeds by the river?” After seeing this title character, Mary gives birth to the evil Helen Vaughan in a novella by Arthur (*) Machen. This being titles another Barrett Browning poem based on Plutarch’s “On the Failure of Oracles,” in which a mysterious voice tells the sailor Thamus that this god is dead. In The Wind and the Willows, he appears as “The Piper at the Gates of Dawn.” For 10 points, name this Greek god who represents nature in the works of many English writers because he is half-man and half-goat.
tossups.answer: Pan [or The Great God Pan] (The stories mentioned are “The Story of a Panic,” “The Music on the Hill,” and The Great God Pan.) <Literature - British>

tossups.question: The “Human Cloning” and “Marker Realization” rules are identified in a paper arguing that certain suffixes in this language are declension-class markers rather than gender markers by James W. Harris, who studied this language throughout his career. Certain dialects of this language employ the unusual voiceless denti-alveolar sibilant. A minimal pair between this language’s words for “hunt” and “house” occurs for the vast majority of its speakers because they realize voiceless dental (*) fricatives as voiceless alveolar sibilants. Jane Hill outlined a “mock” form of this language consisting of phrases used for humor by using examples from the film Terminator 2: Judgment Day. Phonological variations in this language’s dialects include seseo and yeísmo. For 10 points, name this language, some speakers of which use the second-person subject form “vos” instead of “tú.”
tossups.answer: Spanish [or Español, Castellano, or Castilian; accept Mock Spanish or Rioplatense Spanish] <Social Science>

tossups.question: The Reisebuch of Johann Schiltberger opens with an account of this battle, whose losers marched east from Oryahovo, where they had massacred the population after promising clemency. Henry V’s palings at Agincourt may have been inspired by this battle, which saw an opening charge stymied after the akinji light cavalry withdrew to reveal rows of pointed stakes. The nominal commander of this battle wanted to send in horse archers ahead of a direct (*) cavalry charge, but was rejected by the heir to the Duke of Burgundy. Stefan Lazarevich’s Serbs took part in this battle as vassals of the winning side. At this battle, a large army under Philip of Artois, Mircea the Elder, John the Fearless, and Sigismund of Hungary was surprised and routed while besieging a fort on the Danube. For 10 points, name this 1396 battle in northern Bulgaria where the Ottomans under Bayezid I crushed an international alliance of Crusaders, whose name is Greek for the “City of Victory.”
tossups.answer: Battle of Nicopolis [or the Crusade of Nicopolis] <History - Mediterranean+>

tossups.question: Michael Bender discovered that insolation variation alters these structures’ gas composition, a fact that can be used to establish the chronology of orbital tuning. Major variations over time in the fluxes of terrestrial iron and calcium found in these objects from the Dome C site reflect fluctuations in the amount of Aeolian dust arriving from Patagonia. EPICA, GISP, and GRIP are consortia formed to collect these objects from sites like Valkyrie Dome. They’re not from the ocean, but the occurrence of Dansgaard-Oeschger events was first discovered in these objects by measuring the (*) fractionation of oxygen-18 and deuterium within them. These objects, which provide the highest-resolution temperature record through the Middle and Late Pleistocene, can be up to three kilometers long and contain air bubbles trapped in clathrates that are used to measure past atmospheric gas concentrations. For 10 points, name these objects which are drilled at sites like Vostok in Antarctica.
tossups.answer: ice cores [prompt on partial answer] <Science - Other>

tossups.question: At the opening of a string quartet by this composer, the first violin plays the loud half notes “D, C-sharp,” followed the eighths [read slowly] “A-A-A B-flat,” then the slurred quarters “F, E-flat.” After suffering a heart attack, this composer wrote a String Trio that has two numbered Episodes between its three Parts. This composer wrote a solo violin part by itself and then its piano accompaniment for the late work Phantasy. In the fourth movement of one of this composer’s works, the soprano enters singing lyrics that mean “I feel air from another planet.” This brother-in-law and student of Alexander von (*) Zemlinsky had a soprano sing two Stefan George poems in his second string quartet. At the “Scandal Concert,” this composer conducted his first Chamber Symphony. A song cycle by this composer popularized the ensemble of flute, clarinet, violin, cello, and piano. For 10 points, what pioneer of atonality invented the twelve-tone system?
tossups.answer: Arnold Schoenberg <Arts - Auditory>  Chicago Open 2019: What If We Kissed 😳 in the Non-Western Art Distribution 😳  Edited by Chris Ray, Jacob Reed, Alston Boyd, Will Holub-Moorman, Jonathan Magin, and Sriram Pendyala, with contributions by Wonyoung Jang and Michael Kearney.  Packet by Fianna Failsons (Mike Bentley, Matt Bollinger, Mike Cheyne, Shan Kothari) and Our Post-Cumin Future (Ian Dewan, Zach Foster, Zhenglin Liu, Chris Sims)  Bonuses

bonuses.leadin: For 10 points each—answer the following about photography and the New York Subway system:
answer: Cunningham (Bill Cunningham and Imogen Cunningham) <Arts - Visual>
parts: This artist first came to prominence after Tseng Kwong Chi photographed him using chalk to draw on blank ad spaces in the subway. This AIDS activist often placed pairs of short lines around his figures to indicate movement.
This photographer’s renowned speed partially came from his use of a portable darkroom in the subway. This man supposedly said that the secret to his technique was “f/8 [“f-stop 8”] and be there”

Photographer Editta Sherman was photographed in a heavily-graffitied subway car by a man with this last name, who did fashion and street photography for the New York Times until his death in 2016. A photographer with this last name was photographed alongside the model Twinka in Yosemite Park by Judy Dater.

bonuses.leadin: This method takes the logarithm of a dataset’s probability given model parameters, and sets its derivative with respect to those model parameters to zero. For 10 points each:
parts: Identify this method which selects a particular parameter value. Because it is efficient, the results of this process attain the Cramér–Rao bound in the limit.

The variance of a maximum likelihood estimator is given by the inverse of the information named for this statistician. He also names a fundamental theorem of natural selection and a runaway phenomenon in sexual selection.
Joe Felsenstein developed maximum likelihood methods for constructing these things, as well as developing the method of independent contrasts for controlling for these things in regression analysis.

bonuses.leadin: This man commissioned Leon Battista Alberti to build him what may have been the first pagan temple constructed in Europe since the Classical era. For 10 points each:
answer: Sigismondo Malatesta [or Sigismondo Pandolfo Malatesta; prompt on the Wolf of Rimini; prompt on partial answer]
Francesca da Rimini [or Francesca da Polenta]
Cesare Borgia [or Duca Valentino; or Duc De Valentinois; prompt on partial answer] <History - Mediterranean+>
parts: Identify this ruler, the target of a 1461 crusade issued by Pope Pius II. After this man's death, his city was taken by his illegitimate son Roberto il Magnifico.
An earlier member of Rimini's Malatesta family, Paolo, is best remembered today for his love affair with this daughter of Guido da Polenta, an incident that condemned her to Hell according to Dante.
Sigismondo's grandson lost control of Rimini to a Papal States army led by this man. This man conquered Urbino without firing a shot, but had his plans derailed by the Magione Conspiracy.

bonuses.leadin: This concept was introduced in a 2010 paper by Joseph Henrich, Steven Heine, and Ara Norenzayan. For 10 points each:
answer: WEIRD [or Western, Educated, Industrialized, Rich, and Democratic]
parts: Name this acronym which the three psychologists used to refer to the populations that are vastly overrepresented in most psychological studies, which tend to favor Americans and Europeans.

An example of the “WEIRD” effect is this optical illusion named for a German psychologist, in which two lines bisecting parallelograms appear to be of different lengths. Non-European subjects tended to be less fooled.

According to a 1966 paper co-authored by this thinker, Western people are more susceptible to the Sander illusion because they live in “carpentered worlds.” This anthropologist also wrote The Myth of the Negro Past.

bonuses.leadin: Poems depicting the journeys of these figures were often written in the loping, seventeen-syllable Mandākrānta meter. For 10 points each:
answer: messengers [or dūta; or “The Cloud Messenger; or “Meghadūta” prompt on sandehahara]
parts: Identify this kind of figure―often a bird or an aspect of the weather―whose travels are central to the genre of sandesha kāvya. In a poem in that genre, one of these figures passes the “dread shrine” of Shiva in Ujjain on its way to Alakā.

This Sanskrit writer’s poem The Cloud Messenger is among the most revered of Indian message-poems. A signet ring breaks a curse that keeps King Dushyanta from recognizing his wife in his play The Recognition of Shakuntalā.

In a stanza attributed to this poet, a cloud laments “What, have I with my showers let fall the moon?” He is better known for codifying classical Sanskrit grammar in his verse treatise Ashtādhyāyī [ush-tah-dyah-yee].

bonuses.leadin: Seven cities are depicted with their names on one side of the “Libya” artifact of this type, while the “Min” example depicts a crook staff crossed with a double-facing arrow. For 10 points each:
answer: Ancient Egyptian cosmetic palettes [or the Libya palette; or the Min palette; prompt on tablet or generic answer]
Narmer [or Menes, Mena, Meni, Min, or Aha; or Scorpion according to THE ROCK]
Nine Bows [prompt on partial answer] <History - Other/World>
parts: Name this type of artifact often used in conjunction with kohl, a substance made from galena. Another of them depicts two serpopards with intertwined necks that are held by two servants with leashes.
Crests containing two hieroglyphs shaped like a catfish and a chisel appear on both sides of the most famous Egyptian cosmetic palette, which is named for this Pharaoh credited with unifying Egypt.

A reconstruction of the Scorpion Macehead depicts three standards with these symbols hanging from them by a rope. These symbols, which are under the feet of the bronze Sphinx statuette of Thutmose III, are frequently used to represent the many enemies of Egypt.

bonuses.leadin: A poem by this author ends “Keep we must, if keep we can / These foreign laws of God and man.” For 10 points each:
answer: a storm [or a gale; or heavy winds] <Literature - British>
parts: Name this poet, who examined nature in poems beginning “Tell me not here, it needs not saying” and “We’ll to the woods no more.”

Since “to look at things in bloom / Fifty springs are little room,” the speaker of a Housman poem resolves to see this tree “hung with snow.” That second poem in A Shropshire Lad praises this “loveliest of trees.”
The speaker of another Housman poem observes this natural phenomenon “On Wenlock Edge,” and imagines how this phenomenon similarly disquieted an ancient Roman viewing it from the city of Uricon.

bonuses.leadin: This piece was originally written for orchestra, but is now probably better-known in the composer’s oratorio version and in his version for string quartet. For 10 points each:
answer: The Seven Last Words of Christ [or The Seven Last Words of Our Savior on the Cross or similar translations; or Die sieben letzten Worte unseres Erlösers am Kreuze]
parts: Name this 1787 piece that comprises a slow introduction, a set of seven slow “sonatas” in wide-ranging key signatures, and a very fast “Earthquake.”
The Seven Last Words of Christ was written by this composer who set texts from Genesis and Paradise Lost in the oratorio The Creation.
The Creation opens with a “Representation” of this phenomenon, which Haydn depicts with slow-moving, ambiguous harmonies and missing cadences. The specific term is needed.

bonuses.leadin: According to El-Sayed’s rule, the rate of these electronic transitions is much higher when they occur between different types of molecular orbitals. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this kind of nonradiative electronic transition from a singlet state to a triplet state, or vice versa, that occurs when potential energy curves for the two states intersect.

When a triplet excited state undergoes decay, it can convert and dissipate its excess energy entirely as heat via this mechanism. This mechanism is essential in plants since the alternative involves the formation of singlet oxygen, which can damage tissues.
The tendency for electrons to get trapped in triplet states due to intersystem crossing helps to explain this photoluminescent phenomenon, which occurs over much longer time-scales than fluorescence.

bonuses.leadin: Like most Class Enemies, Elen Molokhovets was fond of aspics, which she included in this country’s massively popular cookbook, A Gift to Young Housewives. For 10 points each:
answer: Russia [or the USSR; or the Soviet Union; etc]
Richard II [or Richard of Bordeaux]  <Mythology and Other>
parts: Identify this country where the more properly socialist Book of Tasty and Healthy Foods was compiled by Anastas Mikoyan, though it had to have the Stalin quotes removed later on.

This much earlier food writer called for ingredients like sow’s udder, dormice, pennyroyal, and must in his recipes. Seneca claimed he poisoned himself after realizing he could no longer afford his lavish diet, so he probably wasn’t a very good socialist either.

This English king’s master chefs produced the medieval manual Forme of Cury, which makes extensive use of sugar. It’s hard to be more of a Class Enemy than this man, who faced a revolt by the Lords Appellant.

bonuses.leadin: A group of players of these instruments gained headlines in America by running the 1975 Boston Marathon in their distinctive uniforms. For 10 points each:
answer: Toshirō Mifune [accept names in either order] <Arts - Audiovisual, Other>
parts: Name these traditional drums often played by people wearing only headbands and loincloths. These instruments are the centerpiece of an Earth Celebration held each year on Sado Island.
An ō-tsuzumi taiko drum is one of the four instruments played by the hayashi in this oldest extant form of Japanese drama, which uses masks typically made from cypress wood.

This actor played an expert taiko drummer in the 1958 film Rickshaw Man. This actor often characterized his roles with physical mannerisms like exaggeratedly shrugging his shoulders and scratching himself.

bonuses.leadin: This novel’s title character is torn between his wife Esther, his assistant Magda, and his married lover Emilia. For 10 points each:
answer: The Magician of Lublin [or Der kuntsnmakher fun Lublin]
parts: Identify this novel originally serialized in the newspaper Forverts. It ends with the title character bricking himself up in a courtyard, adopting the name Red Jacob the Penitent, and deciding to stop performing.
The Magician of Lublin was written by this Nobel-winning Polish-American author, who wrote The Family Moskat and Enemies: A Love Story in Yiddish.

Singer wrote many ironic stories about the “wise men” of this Polish village. Those stories are based on Jewish folklore, which is chock-full of legends about the foolishness of the people living here.

bonuses.leadin: In this technique, phase-modulated light from a laser is coupled to a resonant cavity, and the demodulated reflected signal from the cavity used to control the laser. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this technique used to lock the frequency of a laser to a resonant cavity in order to reduce its linewidth.

The Pound–Drever–Hall technique is an important component of the “optical” variety of these devices. One of these devices relying on a “fountain” of caesium atoms is used for NIST-F1 and NIST-F2, the primary U.S. frequency standards.

Converting the high frequency signal of an optical atomic clock to an RF signal typically requires a frequency comb, in which the laser pulse train is stabilized by this technique. In this technique, the pump current is modulated to produce short-duration pulses.

bonuses.leadin: This man proposed the use of “sulphur ships,” massive suicide stink bombs designed to clear French coastal forts, though his plan was rejected by the Crown for being crazy and disgusting. For 10 points each:
answer: Lord Thomas Cochrane, 10th Earl of Dundonald [prompt on Dundonald]
parts: Identify this British naval commander, called the “Sea Wolf” by Napoleon, who inspired Patrick O’Brian’s Master and Commander before taking the port of Valdivia for a navy on a different continent.
Thomas Cochrane captured the frigate Esmeralda while commanding the Navy of this man, a part-Irish commander who won the battles of Maipu and Chacabuco and became the father of Chilean independence.

Cochrane’s prolific career included patenting the “tunnelling shield” along with this man, who used it to build the first underwater tunnel in the world across the Thames. This engineer also oversaw the Great Western Railway.

bonuses.leadin: In a treatise on these problems, Thomas Bradwardine argued against restrictions on self-referential statements, claiming that statements implying their own untruth must be both true and false. For 10 points each:
answer: insolubles [or insolubilia; or insolubile; prompt on sophismata or sophisms]
parts: Give this general term used by medieval philosophers to describe paradoxes of self-reference like the Liar’s paradox. Much medieval interest in these problems was sparked by a passage in Aristotle’s Sophistical Refutations.

Bradwardine and other philosophers interested in insolubles formed this group, including William Heytesbury and John Dumbleton. Members of this group made mathematical discoveries like the mean speed theorem.

This French philosopher returned to questions about insolubles throughout his career, generally arguing that they are false. He’s also the namesake of a paradox about an ass caught between two bundles of hay.

bonuses.leadin: For 10 points each—answer the following about the theology of Reformed Baptist author John Piper:
parts: In his book Desiring God, Piper coined this term to describe the doctrine that Christians should “glorify God by enjoying Him forever.” A philosophical version of this position was defended by the Cyrenaics.
Piper believes that this event will occur after the Great Tribulation. The Left Behind series begins with this event, in which true Christian believers will be taken up to Heaven.

Piper’s Recovering Biblical Manhood and Womanhood defends this belief, according to which husbands should lead and wives should submit, but both are “valuable.” This stance is contrasted with both gender egalitarianism and pure male chauvinism.

bonuses.leadin: A persistent problem in evolutionary genetics is that evolutionary histories inferred from different genes are often incongruent. For 10 points each:
answer: incomplete lineage sorting [or ILS; prompt on partial answer]
gene duplication [prompt on answers involving the formation of DNA repeats] <Science - Biology>
parts: One cause of gene tree incongruence is genetic recombination that occurs during this phenomenon, which often occurs in namesake zones where reproductively compatible species overlap. As Haldane’s rule implies, this process does not always result in sterile offspring.
This term is often used to describe situations in which allelic lineages fail to segregate among species, usually because speciation occurs faster than coalescence.

Gene tree incongruence can also occur when speciation follows this phenomenon. These events create paralogs, one of which is often silenced and, like deletions, they often result from chromosomal rearrangements like ectopic recombination.

bonuses.leadin: Deaths from opioid overdoses are often a prime candidate for this procedure. For 10 points each:
parts: Identify this procedure, which happens at the highest rate in Spain due to an opt-in by default policy begun in 1979. This procedure can be complicated when immune responses by the recipient lead to rejection.

Those who declined organs from Hepatitis C-positive donors outcomes actually had worse outcomes than those who accepted them between 2010 and 2014. That’s in large part due to this expensive drug from Gilead which can cure Hepatitis C after a 12-week course.

1.6% of all US exports in 2016 were in the form of blood plasma. The documentary Factor 8 explores how prisoners from this state donated huge quantities of tainted plasma, causing haemophilia. Betty Bumpers, a first lady of this state, was a tireless advocate for childhood vaccinations.

bonuses.leadin: The narrator compares this urge to the feeling of standing on the edge of an abyss, and being drawn closer to the edge until plunging into it. For 10 points each:
answer: being buried alive [or “The Premature Burial”; or other equivalents to being buried alive] <Literature - American>
parts: Name this urge. In a short story named for it, the narrator commits the perfect murder and gets away with it until this urge compels him to confess in public.
This author of “The Imp of the Perverse” wrote about characters compelled to murder by sudden perverse impulses in stories like “The Black Cat.”

The title character of Poe’s story “Berenice” suffers this fate after the narrator yanks out all of her teeth. In another Poe story, the cataleptic narrator cites the case of Edward Stapleton to explain why he is terrified of experiencing it.

bonuses.leadin: Lies My Teacher Told Me author James W. Loewen wrote a book about the roughly 25,000 American towns that enforced these types of laws. For 10 points each:
answer: sundown laws [or sunset laws; or gray laws]
parts: Give this name for laws and other unwritten codes that prohibited African Americans from being in certain towns overnight.

This modern-day state banned all African Americans from entering its territory in 1844 under penalty of lashing. In the 20th century, this geographically anomalous Klan stronghold sought to ban private schools to reduce the rights of Catholics.

In Buchanan v. Warley, the Supreme Court ruled that this city’s laws banning blacks from owning property in majority-white neighborhoods was unconstitutional. In the early 20th century, this city’s politics were controlled by “The Buckingham Boss,” John Henry Whallen.
